linkTarget.anchoringText: The Cooper Basin is located in central Australia (Fig. 1) and is the largest onshore hydrocarbon producing province in Australia with a cumulative production of approximately 5.4 TCF of gas, 197 MMBBLS oil and 80 MMBBLS of condensation (DSD, 2017). To date the vast majority of these hydrocarbons have been produced from conventional and tight sandstones reservoirs, however as conventional targets mature, exploration emphasis has increasingly moved towards unconventional reservoir exploitation.

image-wrap.label: Figure 1
image-wrap.caption: Location map of the Cooper Basin

formatted-caption.caption-text: Location map of the Cooper Basin

linkTarget.anchoringText: The Cooper-Eromanga Basin developed as an intra-cratonic sag during thermal relaxation, after a period of granite emplacement in the late Carboniferious-to-Early Permian (Fig. 2). This event marked the end of the Alice Springs Orogeny which was characterised by north-south intraplate compression between the Late Ordovician and the start of the Permian (Haines et al., 2001), although periodic events may have continued through to the Mid-Permian. Figures 3a and 3b show the general geology of the North Patchawarra Trough and a seismic cross-section showing Mid-Permian (Artinskian) compression on the Moondie High.

image-wrap.label: Figure 2
image-wrap.caption: Senex Ltd stratigraphic column for the Cooper-Eromanga Basin sequence showing Patchawarra Formation coal target zone in red box and V50 coal target discussed in text.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Senex Ltd stratigraphic column for the Cooper-Eromanga Basin sequence showing Patchawarra Formation coal target zone in red box and V50 coal target discussed in text.

linkTarget.anchoringText: The Cooper-Eromanga Basin developed as an intra-cratonic sag during thermal relaxation, after a period of granite emplacement in the late Carboniferious-to-Early Permian (Fig. 2). This event marked the end of the Alice Springs Orogeny which was characterised by north-south intraplate compression between the Late Ordovician and the start of the Permian (Haines et al., 2001), although periodic events may have continued through to the Mid-Permian. Figures 3a and 3b show the general geology of the North Patchawarra Trough and a seismic cross-section showing Mid-Permian (Artinskian) compression on the Moondie High.

image-wrap.label: Figure 3
image-wrap.caption: a) Time structure map of the V50 coal in the North Patchawarra Trough area of interest showing key wells and seismic surveys, and b) 2D seismic line 95-fsd_mig across the Moondie anticline showing the thinning of the uppermost Patchawarra Formation and onlap of the basal Epsilon Formation coal, denoting a mid-Permian (Artinskian) uplift event after V50 coal deposition. The area is proximal to pipelines (black lines) and established infrastructure.

formatted-caption.caption-text: a) Time structure map of the V50 coal in the North Patchawarra Trough area of interest showing key wells and seismic surveys, and b) 2D seismic line 95-fsd_mig across the Moondie anticline showing the thinning of the uppermost Patchawarra Formation and onlap of the basal Epsilon Formation coal, denoting a mid-Permian (Artinskian) uplift event after V50 coal deposition. The area is proximal to pipelines (black lines) and established infrastructure.

figure-specific-caption.caption-text: Time structure map of the V50 coal in the North Patchawarra Trough area of interest showing key wells and seismic surveys
2D seismic line 95-fsd_mig across the Moondie anticline showing the thinning of the uppermost Patchawarra Formation and onlap of the basal Epsilon Formation coal

linkTarget.anchoringText: Available palynological data for 107 wells were used to map palynostratigraphic sub-divisions of the Patchawarra Formation using the maximum flooding surface of each sub-division as the mappable surface (Fig. 4). Within the study area, a number of key coal seams meet both minimum thickness and maturity requirements as deep coal gas targets. The V50 coal seam, which is defined by the upper PP2.2.1 palynological zone (Fig. 2), ranges between 16 and 21m thickness and has a measured maturity at wells exceeding Ro 1.1%, making it a prime gas candidate.

image-wrap.label: Figure 4
image-wrap.caption: Palynostratigraphic subdivision of mappable coal units in the Patchawarra Formation of the North Patchawarra Trough for key wells (locations shown in Figure 3). Of the seams in this area, the V50 is one of several prime candidates which meets minimum thickness and maturity requirements as a deep coal gas target.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Palynostratigraphic subdivision of mappable coal units in the Patchawarra Formation of the North Patchawarra Trough for key wells (locations shown in Figure 3). Of the seams in this area, the V50 is one of several prime candidates which meets minimum thickness and maturity requirements as a deep coal gas target.

linkTarget.anchoringText: The palynologically defined V50 coal was mapped using available 3D and 2D seismic data in the North Patchawarra Trough (Fig. 3) after the generation of well synthetics for the key wells in the study area (Fig. 5). The representative amplitude for the V50, like all coals, is highly variable and "seam splits" are common as a function of varying depositional system. In understanding the variation in fluvial depositional systems, a spectral decomposition time slice at −2131 msec TWT was extracted from the Jonothon and Coolibah 3D volumes, in the centre of the resource area, approximating a time slice just above the V50 coal.

image-wrap.label: Figure 5
image-wrap.caption: 3D seismic correlation of some key coal horizons across the the Delaware, Coolibah and Jonothon 3D volumes in the North Patcahwarra Trough (line location shown on Figure 3).

formatted-caption.caption-text: 3D seismic correlation of some key coal horizons across the the Delaware, Coolibah and Jonothon 3D volumes in the North Patcahwarra Trough (line location shown on Figure 3).

linkTarget.anchoringText: The time slice highlights amplitude and phase at different frequencies to emphasise geomorphologic features which can be interpreted, in conjunction with well and palynological data, as a broad GDE map (Fig. 6). The GDE illustrates a NE-flowing meandering river system and is consistent with walk-out plot interpretations from FMI data at Washington-1, and that coal facies are variably deposited across the trough at different stratigraphic levels. This information is incorporated within the resource model.

image-wrap.label: Figure 6
image-wrap.caption: a) Spectral decomposition time slice at −2131 msTWT in the central North Patchawarra Trough in the Jonothon and Coolibah 3D seismic volumes. The time slice approximates the section directly above the V50 Patachawarra coal, and b) an interpreted Gross Depositional Environment (GDE) map broadly illustrating fluvial systems at this time slice, noting that coal facies are only interpreted in mires either side of channel systems.

formatted-caption.caption-text: a) Spectral decomposition time slice at −2131 msTWT in the central North Patchawarra Trough in the Jonothon and Coolibah 3D seismic volumes. The time slice approximates the section directly above the V50 Patachawarra coal, and b) an interpreted Gross Depositional Environment (GDE) map broadly illustrating fluvial systems at this time slice, noting that coal facies are only interpreted in mires either side of channel systems.

figure-specific-caption.caption-text: Spectral decomposition time slice at −2131 msTWT in the central North Patchawarra Trough in the Jonothon and Coolibah 3D seismic volumes
an interpreted Gross Depositional Environment (GDE) map broadly illustrating fluvial systems at this time slice, noting that coal facies are only interpreted in mires either side of channel systems

linkTarget.anchoringText: Seismically mapped sequences from across the Cooper Basin, including intra-Patchawarra Formation sequences, have been depth converted and incorporated with coal electro-facies isopachs within a 3D Trinity multi-variant basin model. Figure 7 is an extract of this model within the area of interest for this study. The Trinity model incorporates some aspects of the published Geoscience Australia basin model (Hall et al. 2016).

image-wrap.label: Figure 7
image-wrap.caption: Extract from a calibrated basin-wide 3D multi-variant Trinity model showing P50 estimate of free retained plus 5% adsorbed gas (BCF/km2) for Patchawarra coals within the Area of Interest. Resource density is highest in the central PEL 638 area. The map also shows mapped structural closures at the V50 coal level (A-F) and an area of out-ofclosure exploration, Moondie East, which is within the >1.1 Ro% maturity cut-off and <8% porosity (permeability gaol).

formatted-caption.caption-text: Extract from a calibrated basin-wide 3D multi-variant Trinity model showing P50 estimate of free retained plus 5% adsorbed gas (BCF/km2) for Patchawarra coals within the Area of Interest. Resource density is highest in the central PEL 638 area. The map also shows mapped structural closures at the V50 coal level (A-F) and an area of out-ofclosure exploration, Moondie East, which is within the >1.1 Ro% maturity cut-off and <8% porosity (permeability gaol).

linkTarget.anchoringText: The Patchawarra Formation V50 coal amplitude in the Jonothon and Coolibah 3D surveys was assessed using a maximum amplitude extraction of ±10 ms on the curvature volume (Fig. 8a). The extracted curvature volume shows a number of trends, often in conjugate pairs and with no single constant trend across all volumes. Available FMI data for wells within the volume were assessed and rose plots for fractures in the Permian succession, mainly Patchawarra Formation, are shown in Figure 8b.

image-wrap.label: Figure 8
image-wrap.caption: a) 3D curvature extraction for the Patchawarra Formation V50 coal amplitude in the 3D Jonothon and Coolibah surveys showing multiple conjugate trends which vary in orientation across the surveys, b) a structural analsyis of curvature trends also using available FMI data from the Permian succession. Conductive (green) and resistive (red) fractures agree well with fracture trends extracted from the curvature volume. SHmax trends derived from FMI breakout and DITFs consistently trend NW (red dotted lines) at an angle of 20-35° from from conductive fracture set. Sinistral shear zones are interpreted within the fracture sets which are likely to represent tectonic fratures of Mid-Permian age.

formatted-caption.caption-text: a) 3D curvature extraction for the Patchawarra Formation V50 coal amplitude in the 3D Jonothon and Coolibah surveys showing multiple conjugate trends which vary in orientation across the surveys, b) a structural analsyis of curvature trends also using available FMI data from the Permian succession. Conductive (green) and resistive (red) fractures agree well with fracture trends extracted from the curvature volume. SHmax trends derived from FMI breakout and DITFs consistently trend NW (red dotted lines) at an angle of 20-35° from from conductive fracture set. Sinistral shear zones are interpreted within the fracture sets which are likely to represent tectonic fratures of Mid-Permian age.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Vertical anisotropy in stress response is driven by changes in rock properties between lithologies (mechanical stratigraphy) and has been described in the Cooper Basin Permian section by Nelson et al. (2007). An example MEM for Jute-1 is shown in Figure 9. Furthermore both coals and sandstones can exhibit both break-out and tensile failure, implying that differential stress in the Permian section is high (Tyiasning and Cooke, 2016).

image-wrap.label: Figure 9
image-wrap.caption: Extract of a composite 1D Mechanicam Earth Model (MEM) for Jute-1 within the North Patchawarra Trough deep coal play. The model also utilises DFIT data from Washington-1 to calibrate Shmin and hoop stress calculations from observed break-outs in the Jute-1 FMI (locations shown in Figure 3). The model shows strong vertical stress variation associated with variations in mechanical stratigraphy. Compressive stress (grey shading) increase to the right with most sandstones in strike-slip or reverse stress state. Red arrow heads indicate where sandstones have Shmax>Shmin>Sv (reverse stress). Blue shading to the left denotes a normal stress state, most common in coals.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Extract of a composite 1D Mechanicam Earth Model (MEM) for Jute-1 within the North Patchawarra Trough deep coal play. The model also utilises DFIT data from Washington-1 to calibrate Shmin and hoop stress calculations from observed break-outs in the Jute-1 FMI (locations shown in Figure 3). The model shows strong vertical stress variation associated with variations in mechanical stratigraphy. Compressive stress (grey shading) increase to the right with most sandstones in strike-slip or reverse stress state. Red arrow heads indicate where sandstones have Shmax>Shmin>Sv (reverse stress). Blue shading to the left denotes a normal stress state, most common in coals.

linkTarget.anchoringText: As coal rock strength will likely remain a drilling challenge, this would be best addressed by casing off the up-hole section prior to increasing mud-weights in the horizontal production hole, using a clay inhibiting drilling fluid and running screens. Figure 10 shows conceptual horizontal pilot wells for both scenarios presented in this study with the target coal at ~3200mSS and the curvature volume displayed.

image-wrap.label: Figure 10
image-wrap.caption: 3D view of a pilot area D in figure 7 in the Crocus North area as the closure dependent sub play test. A planned 1000m lateral well through the V50 coal shown as the amplitude extraction with curvature volume. Also shown is the Moondie East closure independent area with pilot 1000m lateral wells. The V50 coal target at both pilot areas is at ~3200mSS depth.

formatted-caption.caption-text: 3D view of a pilot area D in figure 7 in the Crocus North area as the closure dependent sub play test. A planned 1000m lateral well through the V50 coal shown as the amplitude extraction with curvature volume. Also shown is the Moondie East closure independent area with pilot 1000m lateral wells. The V50 coal target at both pilot areas is at ~3200mSS depth.
